Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2011 12:57PM KellyMaryland wrote: I've had both. For me (and I know some others have NOT had this experience) the MRI guided biopsy was not pleasant.  How do you do with anesthesia? If it were me, I'd go for the excisional- you're asleep for it and you're more likely to get definitive results.  Where I am, the radiologists do the MRI biopsies and the breast surgeons do the excisionals.  Is that the same for you? Do you have one doctor that you prefer?
Posts.Title: could this be the case flowerfloosey barbe1958

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2011 06:44AM KellyMaryland wrote: Hi. So sorry for your stress.  I wanted to respond because I had a similar experience.  When I was about 10 weeks pregnant with my last child, I found not exactly a lump but a thickening.  This was my fourth child so I had been pregnant and had nursed the others so it seemed that my breasts were always changing.  My gyno referrred me to a breast surgeon and though she thought it was a benign area (she was right), she did perform a core needle biopsy there in the office.  I was followed for this lump during the pregnancy, after the pregnancy while nursing and after I stopped nursing- physical exams, ultrasounds, mammos.  Though the spot didn't grow over time, it didn't go away as the docs thought it would after pregnancy and nursing stopped so I opted to get the area surgically removed.  The pathology result from that was PLCIS (not exactly cancer...a very grey area and much debated breast disease).  I was really lucky to have time to make decisions before I was forced to, something I am profoundly grateful for.  I tell you all this not to further stress you only to encourage you to follow your gut.  A call to the breast clinic about your concerns may be in order.  My best advice to you is not to panic but don't belittle your feelings that something is not right.  Keep us posted. All the best, Kelly

Never had it done so I don't know much about it other than, similar to breast MRI, an injectible dye is used.  Hope this helps. All the best, Kelly

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 11:14AM KellyMaryland wrote: Hi Momma. Sorry for your tough decisions ahead.  I wasn't diagnosed with ADH, but another (further down the road to cancer) thing called pleomorphic LCIS.  I was definitely encouraged to take Tamoxofen by every BS and oncologist I saw.  Like ADH, the risk of invasive disease with LCIS is a lifetime risk, so I don't understand why, as posted above, tamox wouldn't be recommended for ADH. Momma, I asked that very question, "what if the cancer to be isn't er pos?" and was told that it's kind of a crap shoot but most breast cancers are er pos.

Posts.Title: MRI susan_CNY susan_CNY

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2011 05:23PM KellyMaryland wrote: Hi Kay. I'll be thinking of you tomorrow, hoping for happy results.  So the MRI biopsy: in my experience you get the IV for the contrast dye and lie down on the MRI table.  A grid-like plate is placed beside each breast, holding it in place and making it easier for the doctor to find the right spot.  Then they send you into the machine for a short bit to get the images and bring you back out when they're ready to do the biopsy.  The doctor gives you lidocaine (I had to ask for lots more than she originally gave so don't be silent if you need more pain meds.) and biopsies the spots.  For me, the whole thing took about an hour.  Afterwards they give you a little ice pack, though I really didn't need it long.  I recently had preventative bilateral mastectomies- no family history but personal history of PLCIS and other benign but funky stuff.  I'm happy to talk to you about my experience if you like.  For the meantime, just breathe, get through tomorrow.  Sending you lots of strength. Kelly

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2011 01:51AM KellyMaryland wrote: this is quite a family history. i don't have one so can't speak to that.  would you be comfortable talking to your gyno about it? maybe even getting a referral to a breast specialist- there are many high-risk clinics out there that may be an option for you.  it may help you feel more in control if you are meeting with doctors who specialize in high-risk treatment.  they may be able to allay some of your fears, make lifestyle recommenations, recommend earlier breast imaging.  being armed with some extra knowledge and feeling that you are being cared for and respected by a breast professional may be just what you need to not let the fear get the best of you.  wishing you well, kelly

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2011 08:24AM KellyMaryland wrote: Hi everyone. I've read through all of your writings- the happy news, the sad news. I'm thinking of all of you and though I've had my surgery over a week ago (Jan. 26th), I haven't been able to write.  I thought I'd feel immense relief but really I just feel kind of blank. Not sad exactly, almost lonely, though I'm surrounded by caring people.  And frankly, I've felt guilty writing because my surgery was a prophylactic one so I don't even have to deal with the many of the rotten things you all are dealing with.  My surgery was nipple sparing bilateral with TEs. Took about 7 hours. No complications, though they had a hard time finding a good pain control combination so I did stay an extra day so they could get a handle on that.  Both the PS and BS say all looks good and they expect that the skin and nips will survive.  Got a preliminary path report which looked really good- lots of atypia but no cancer. They have one small bit (my original lumpectomy site) that they want to take a closer look at, slice it thinner,etc. to make sure they aren't missing something.  I'll find that out early next week. Was sent home with four drains, two came out Tuesday, another out yesterday and the fourth they expect to come out early next week. I think I've been lucky that the drains don't seem to be an issue for me, just weird. Sending hugs to you all. -Kelly
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2010 09:42AM KellyMaryland wrote: Back from my first pilates class.  Um....lots of stomach strength work to do.  I did want to mention that my instructor stressed the importance of opening the shoulder as much as possible before surgery, particularly for hunchers like me (hunching over shortens the muscles of your chest and shoulder).  For me even pulling my shoulders back in line with my spine feels strange.  She said shoulders should be back and the tops of the shoulders pushed down as if you are creating space between your shoulders and head.  Warmest wishes for a happy and healthy new year for you all. Kelly
